abstract.text: We report a set of measurements of inclusive invariant pT differential cross sections of Λ 0 , Λ 0 , Ξ ± ,
and Ω ± hyperons reconstructed in the central region with pseudorapidity |η| < 1 and pT up to 10 GeV/c.
Events are collected with a minimum-bias trigger in pp collisions at a center-of-mass energy of 1.96 TeV using the CDF II detector at the Tevatron Collider.
As pT increases, the slopes of the differential cross sections of the three particles are similar, which could indicate a universality of the particle production in pT .
The invariant differential cross sections are also presented for different charged-particle multiplicity intervals.

body_text.text: Ever since their discovery in cosmic ray interactions [1], 33 particles containing strange quarks have been extensively 34 studied at particle colliders (e + e − [2], ep [3], pp [4,5] and 35 pp [6]).
The process by which hadrons in general are pro- such as kaons and hyperons [7].
To isolate QGP sig- natures in heavy-ion collision data, understanding the 1 particle production properties from simple nucleon inter-2 actions is necessary.
There are ample data on the production of particles 4 with one strange quark, but very little available on par-5 ticles with two or more [8,9].
Previous studies of hyper-

ons from colliders such as RHIC [6], SppS [10], and the Tevatron [5,11,12] were limited by low sample statistics and the limited accessible range of hyperon momentum 9 component transverse to the beam direction (p T ).
In
this analysis, we report on a study of the hyperons Λ 0
(quark content uds), Ξ − (dss), and Ω − (sss) and their
corresponding antiparticles (Λ 0 , Ξ + , and Ω + ).
The CDF II detector is described in detail else-
where [13].

To reduce 81 backgrounds further, we require the Λ 0 decay length L Λ 0 , 82 the distance in the r − φ plane between the primary and 83 secondary vertices, to be greater than 2.5 cm and less 84 than 50 cm.
The invariant mass M pπ of the two-track system is cal-  ±10% at the lowest p T (1.2 GeV/c) to less than ±5% for cm and that of the Λ 0 candidate to be between 2.5 and 50 cm.
To enhance the selection of Λ 0 from Ξ − decays, we require the difference between the Ξ − and Λ 0 decay lengths to be greater than 1 cm.
Finally, it is required that the d 0 of the Ξ − candidate be less than 0.25 cm and the distance δZ 0 along the z-axis between the Ξ − and the primary vertex be less than 2 cm.
To reconstruct Ω − decays we follow the same procedure as for the Ξ − and apply the same selection criteria except that the third track is assigned the kaon mass.

For the ratio plots, Λ 0 cross sections are recalculated at 58 the Ξ − and Ω − p T values.
In the Ξ − /Λ 0 ratio there is a 59 rise at low p T , and the ratio reaches a plateau at p T > 4
GeV/c.

includes Λ 0 production from the decay of other hyperon states (Σ 0 → Λ 0 γ, Ξ ± , Ξ 0 and Ξ 0 ).
Due to the short Σ 0 lifetime, Λ 0 from Σ 0 decays cannot be separated from direct Λ 0 production.
Simulations of cascade decays indicate that ∼ 50% of Λ 0 from Ξ decays will satisfy our Λ 0 selection criteria, with the fraction of Λ 0 fairly independent of Ξ p T .
The ratio plots in Figure 3 are fitted to a constant, and the value 0.17 ± 0.01 is obtained for Ξ − /Λ 0 and 0.025 ± 0.002 for Ω − /Λ 0 .
The ratio and p T plots in Figure 3 clearly show that the cross sections depend on the number of strange quarks.
However, the plots in Figure 3, n values in Table II  that the p T slopes are similar in the high p T region.
This could be an indication of a universality in particle production as p T increases [26].
This is in contrast to the low p T region where the slope exhibits a strong particle type dependence [27].
18 Figure 4 shows the p T differential cross sections for 19 two charged-particle multiplicity regions, N ch < 10 and 20 N ch > 24.
N ch = 24 (10) corresponds to dN/dη ∼ 16 7, shown for Λ 0 and Ξ − .
We observe a correlation between 25 high p T particles and high multiplicity events.
This is a 26 general characteristic independent of the particle types.

duced from interactions is an unsolved problem in the 37 standard model, and a detailed analysis of production38 properties of particles with different quark flavors and 39 numbers of quarks could pave the way to understanding 40 the process from first principles.

The data on strange 41 particle production can also be used to refine phenomeno-42 logical models and set parameters, such as the strange 43 quark suppression constant in event generators, which 44 have become an integral part of any data analysis.
Inter-45 est in particles containing strange quarks increased with 46 the introduction of the quark-gluon plasma (QGP).
Formation of quark-gluon plasma in a collision could mani-48 fest itself as an enhanced production of strange particles 49
culated by attributing the proton mass to the track with 87 the higher p T , as preferentially expected by the kinemat-88 ics of a Λ 0 decay.
Figure 1 shows the invariant mass for 89 Λ 0 candidates with |η| < 1.

This distribution is divided 90 into 23 p T intervals [18] and the number of Λ 0 in each p T 91 interval is determined by fitting the invariant mass distri-92 butions using a Gaussian function with three parameters 93 for the signal and a third-order polynomial for the under-94 lying combinatorial background.
The data in the mass 95 range 1.10 − 1.16 GeV/c 2 are fitted.
The polynomial fit 96 to the background is subtracted bin-by-bin from the data 97 entries in the Λ 0 mass window (1.111 − 1.121 GeV/c 2 ) 98 to obtain the number of Λ 0 hyperons.
This number is 99 divided by the acceptance to obtain the invariant dif-100 ferential p T distribution as described later.
With our 101 minimum track p T requirement, the Λ 0 p T resolution de-102 creases from ∼0.8% at 1.5 GeV/c to ∼0.6% at 3 GeV/c 103 and slowly increases to ∼1.1% at 10 GeV/c.
The fitting procedure is one source of systematic un-105 certainty.

This uncertainty is estimated by separately 106 varying the mass range of the fit, the functional form 107 for the signal to a double Gaussian, and the background 108 modeling function to a second-order polynomial.
The 109 number of Λ 0 is recalculated in all p T intervals for each 110 variation.
The systematic uncertainty is determined as the sum in quadrature of the fractional change in the number of Λ 0 from each modified fit.
It decreases from

The invariant mass M Λ 0 π is calculated by fixing the mass of the Λ 0 candidate to 1.1157 GeV/c2 [19]  and assigning the pion mass to the third track.Figure 1shows the invariant mass for Ξ − candidates with |η| < 1 overlaid with the fitted curve.As for the Λ 0 case, the Ξ − candidates are divided into 17 p T intervals and the number of Ξ − in each interval is determined by fitting the corresponding M Λ 0 π invariant mass distribution using a Gaussian function for the signal and a third-order polynomial for the background.
The fitted background is then subtracted bin-by-bin from the data entries in the signal region (1.31 to 1.33 GeV/c 2 ) to obtain the Ξ − yield in every p T interval.
The systematic uncertainty of the fit procedure is estimated the same way as for the Λ 0 and is found to change by no more than ±5% in all p T intervals.

This distribution is subtracted from the M Λ 0 K − distribution after normalizing to the number of events in the mass window 1.69 < M Λ 0 K − < 1.74 GeV/c 2 .

The components most relevant to this anal-22 ysis are those that comprise the tracking system, which23 is within a uniform axial magnetic field of 1.4T.
The in-24 ner tracking volume is composed of a system of eight 25 layers of silicon microstrip detectors ranging in radius 26 from 1.5 to 28.0 cm [14] in the pseudorapidity region 27 |η| < 2 [15].
The remainder of the tracking volume 28 is occupied by the Central Outer Tracker (COT).

Once this intersection point, referred to as 75 the secondary vertex, is found, the z-coordinate of each 76 track (Z 1 and Z 2 ) is calculated at that point.
If the 77 distance |Z 1 − Z 2 | is less than 1.5 cm, the tracks are con-78 sidered to originate from a Λ 0 candidate decay.

The previously reconstructed Λ candidates are used, but without the d 0 and δZ 0 requirements.
We select Λ 0 candidates in the Λ mass window and calculate the coordinate of the intersection point in the r − φ plane between the Λ 0 candidate and a third track.
The z-axis coordinates at this point are calculated for the third track (Z 3 ) and the Λ 0 candidate (Z 4 ).
The three-track system is considered a Ξ − candidate decay if the distance |Z 3 −Z 4 | < 1.5 cm.
We also require L Ξ − > 1
